data.title: Dallas History on Display
data.text: This cemetery is a who's who of Dallas founding families...walk through and you get a sense of history..

data.title: Cemetary View of Dallas Skyline/Pioneer Plaza/Cattle Drive Park/Dallas Confederate War Memoriarial and Convention Center
data.text: Many of Dallas' forefathers and mothers were laid to rest here between the Pioneer Plaza and Cattle Drive Park and the Dallas Confederate War Memorial and Convention Center. The view of the Dallas skyline to the north is spectacular with the architectural wonder of Dallas City Hall just blocks away to the east. A perfect place to stop and see all six sites. Just a block off the DART (Dallas Area Rapid Transit) rail system.

data.title: Downtown Cemetery
data.text: Interesting Walk back through the early settlers of Dallas along with a Confederate Monument.  In the Spring and Fall this would be a nice walk.  In the Summer, this was much too hot with little shade.

data.title: Needs to be better kept, and watch out for fire ants
data.text:
A cemetery this old and of historic significance should be better kept. Amazing stories from the pioneers illustrated here.

Also, beware of fire ants.

data.title: Cemetery for some of the original Dallas families
data.text:
The cemetery is adjacent to the Dallas Cattle Drive sculptures.   The graves are from the 1800s and seem to be of the original Dallas settlers.   The monument to Confederate veterans is here too.

My favorite tombstone was one of an angel.  It was quite beautiful with the trees in the background.   The saddest site was the family that buried 10 of their children.

There are some historical markers on some of the graves to help tell the stories.   It's a quite place in downtown

data.title: Historical cemetery
data.text: This cemetery is located in downtown Dallas. It has a deep history connected to it.  Many important people of the area are buried there. They also have a huge civil war monument there along with graves of some soldiers from that war.  I found this cemetery in very good condition and an interesting place to visit and find local history.

data.title: Historically interesting
data.text: The cemetery is quite interesting with several plaques sited on historically poignant graves. One thing that I did notice was that there seemed to be an awful lot of Freemasons buried here and some of the stone work is of a very good standard, nothing untoward just something I noticed. This also includes the Confederate War Memorial.

data.title: Worthwhile
data.text: There's definitely a lot of history in this cemetery.  It was a nice area to walk through.  They had plaques up on many of the historically relevant graves.  It's relatively small so doesn't take much time.  I felt safe in the daylight but doubt I'd want to go after dark.  Limited free parking, but I still found a spot.  Definitely recommended if old cemeteries interest you!

data.title: Memorial to Cattle, Founders, and Fallen Police Officers
data.text: This memorial park is across the street from City Hall, in front of the Dallas Convention Center, about 2 blocks from the Omni Hotel. Some Dallas founders are buried here, and their names are familiar. The cemetery is not primarily a tourist site so there's not much info about the history. It would be interesting if there were an app for this cemetery to give details about these men's stories. The many black cattle statues are worth walking over here for. Whoever made the decision to add them was smart because they commemorate history but add a modern energy to the park and kind of bring the past alive. They're too big to climb on -- this isn't really the kind of park where you'd bring the kids to play. There's also a police memorial here (at the eastern corner). It's made of steel and the fallen police officers' badge numbers are punched out of the metal, so when the sun shines through the numbers they show on the sidewalk. Good place to take a walk if you work nearby, if you're taking a break from a convention, or if you're staying at a hotel nearby and have about a half hour.

data.title: Running with the Bulls.
data.text: This was our second option to seeing a longhorn. It worked out perfect we also got the chance to act out running with the Bulls without getting trampled. The photo opportunity is amazing. The cattle crossing is amazing and free.

data.title: one side is a cemetery the other is a largest sculpture cattle drive
data.text: this park is within walking distance from Dealey plaza. the one side is a quit cemetery but on the other side I found pools of water, waterfalls, stepping stones and a herd of cattle coming down the hill, escorting by three Cowboys on horses. I was amazed when I walked up to these sculptures, that they were life size. it was the coolest thing to see!

data.title: Old cemetery
data.text: If you like touring old cemeteries this might be for you.  Not very large. Nice to walk around.  Good location.

data.title: Another interesting bit of history
data.text: If you're downtown checking out the sculptures, don't miss out on Pioneer Park cemetery. Lots of history right in the middle of downtown. Free admittance and easy parking.

data.title: Nice park
data.text: If your a history buff like I am it's a pretty cool place to see, it's pretty small little area but neat to read the head stones and it's connected to the pioneer plaza so it's a 2 for 1

data.title: Cemetery
data.text: We stumbled on this Cemetery while at Pioneer Plaza looking at the Cattle Drive Sculptures.  It's sad that a lot of the markers have fallen over and aren't legible to read.  A lot of history in this cemetery with the ones you can read.

data.title: Largest sculpture park cattle drive
data.text: This was a quick walk from the Omni Hotel. I was amazed when I walked up to it and here I found pools of water, waterfalls, stepping stones and a herd of cattle coming down the hill, escorting by three Cowboys on horses.  My camera phone captured many angles.  You walk alongside the long horns up to the top of the hill, over yonder is an old Pioneer Cemetery from the early 1800's. Sadly, many of the gravestones have disintegrated with age. You can still read many though. Individual families have plots here. Go to the top of the hill and meander down amongst the long horns!  You won't have to worry about a stampede here!  Just amazing how this is all staged!  A must to visit!

data.title: For all those cemetary lovers
data.text: Loved walking around the old tombstones, yards well kept and a real glimpse of another world 100's of years ago.

data.title: Dallas pioneer
data.text: The names of people who rested here sound familiar around downtown Dallas....yup..there are Dallas pioneers. It's interesting to find out those street names are based on the names of these people. It's an hour good time spent learning the history of Dallas through this cemetery.

data.title: History
data.text: If a map available then take one as it will pin point the location of the history makers of Dallas...

data.title: AMAZING cattle drive in bronze... excellent example of inspiring urban art
data.text: My wife & I tangled with rush hour traffic to downtown in the hopes of finding the 49 head of cattle and 3 trail riders memorialized in bronze next to the Convention Center.  We hadn't realized the beautiful - and MASSIVE - bronze statuary actually "flows" from the Dallas Pioneer Park Cemetery.  We also were concerned about finding parking.  But, at the end of the work day when downtown Dallas folks were going home, we found a small parking lot at the cemetery on the Young Street side.  I see in Google Earth there is another small parking lot on the Griffith Street side of the cemetery grounds.  Personally I think it is soooo appropriate that the artist saved for future generations a "bronze snapshot" of what a cattle drive in 19th century Texas might have looked like.  Oh, for quick reference, the cemetery and the bronze artwork are immediately north of the  Kay Bailey Convention Center.  The cemetery is bounded by the streets of Young, Griffith, and Ceremonial.
